FRS_Method: GPS, WITH CANADIAN ACTIVE CONTROL SYSTEM

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New Equipment - Condensers, Cryolators, and Microprocessors on Compressors.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Clean and inspected air handling units
_prev_prog_3.Description: In an ongoing process to prevent an Ammonia release, we have in place several spill / release prevention programs, emergency response programs, procedures, and safety systems. Our plant SOP's are designed to prevent an accident from occuring and all our operators are trained in safe operating procedures. In the event that we have an ammonia leak, we have NH3 leak detectors for early detection throughout the plant that are centrally monitored 24 hours a day. A Process Safety Management program is in place. An emergency response team is trained in proper emergency response procedures and our specific plan. These emergency responders are available 24 hours per day.

_accidents.CF_Other: Transformer power failure shut off Thermosyphon system. Caused compressor oil to heat up. Heated NH3 caused safety release valve to lift and release at 125 psi.
_accidents.CI_OtherType: Interlocked engine room power with T-4 transformer power. If transformer goes down, compressor shuts down. Microprocessor control was added that will shut down compressors during high temp condition.

_accidents.CF_Other: Lost well motor, cooling water to condensers. Compressor oil heated up causing safety relief valve to lift.
_accidents.CI_OtherType: If pressure is up, above 250 psi, compressor shuts off. Alarm installed in guard shack that indicates if engine room is shut down.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at Rich-SeaPak

Rich-SeaPak prevents accidental releases through classroom and on the job training of refrigeration personnel and ongoing inspection and maintenance of the refrigeration system.  Wherever possible refrigeration system components are located in areas that are not as likely to become damaged (i.e., tanks and pipe runs are placed away and protected from forklift and truck traffic). The facility maintains an ongoing emergency response program that prepares for safe evacuation and timely response by trained personnel.

2.0 Rich-SeaPak and Anhydrous Ammonia.

Rich-SeaPak processes and cools appetizer products for national distribution. Approximately 47,000 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia is contained within the refrigeration system on site at Rich-SeaPak. A Risk Management Plan has been developed as required and is maintained in order to reduce the possibility of an accidental release of ammonia from the system. 

3.0  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps.

Rich-SeaPak complies with all rules and regulations that pertain to the safe storage and use of anhydrous ammonia. Specific regulations include: OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule; OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER); OSHA Hazard Communication (HAZCOM); OSHA Employee Emergency Plans and Fire Prevention Plans; EPA Risk Management Plans (RMP). 

Specific prevention steps that have been implemented to increase the safety of operation of the ammonia refrigeration system include: microprocessors have been installed on all compressors to improve control and safety during a malfunction; ammonia system alarms are linked to the refrigeration office computer for improved monitoring; an engineering review analysis and audit was completed for the ammonia refrigeration system by The Stellar Group on May 12, 2004. One waste water operator is currently participating in RETA level 1 training; cross tr

aining is in progress for all building and grounds, waste water and refrigeration personnel job responsibilities to improve system and equipment knowledge throughout the facility; security fencing with barbed wire has been installed around the facility; security personnel are on site 24 hours, 7 days per week.

4.0  Five Year Accident History.

There has not been any reportable accidents, associated with the ammonia refrigeration system, as defined by 40 CFR Part 68, at Rich-SeaPak in the last five years. There is a record of two ammonia release incidents maintained on file as part of the facility Process Safety Management Program.

5.0  Rich-SeaPak Emergency Response Program.

Rich-SeaPak maintains an ongoing emergency response program in order to efficiently notify and evacuate employees, notify potential critical receptors in the community and state and local emergency response agencies. The program includes initial and annual training for employees who respond to releases or potential releases. The program includes written procedures for proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat human exposures; procedures for using emergency response equipment and procedures to review and update the plan and ensure that employees are informed of changes. The facility emergency response plan is coordinated with the local fire department and Local Emergency Planning Commission, as required by the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act.

6.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety at Rich-SeaPak.

Future plans to improve anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system safety at the Rich-SeaPak facility include: continuing operator training, maintaining the emergency response training program; refrigeration operators will attend Frigo-Scandia spiral freezer maintenance training; hiring additional refrigeration operators; completing a planned ammonia system mechanical integrity inspection; periodic Process Safety Management Program audits, and continuing management of
